Latin Glossary Entries

This glossary includes Latin words listed alphabetically. Each word appears in its original vocabulary form. The glossary contains Latin words of all parts of speech (nouns, adjectives, pronouns, prepositions, verbs, adverbs, idioms, and proper names of people and places).

Identifying a Vocabulary Entry

Nouns

A Latin noun has three parts to it in this order: Nominative singular, Genitive singular, gender. For example:

puella, puellae f.

Puella is the Nominative, singular form of this noun.

Puellae is the Genitive, singular form of this noun.

"F." is the gender of this noun.

Adjective

A 1st and 2nd Declension Latin adjective has three parts (1st and 2nd Declension adjectives) to it in this order: Nominative singular masculine, Nominative singular feminine, Nominative singular neuter. For example:

bonus, bona, bonum

Bonus is the Nominative, singular, masculine form of this adjective.

Bona is the Nominative, singular, feminine form of this adjective.

Bonum is the Nominative, singular, neuter form of this adjective.

A 3rd Declension Latin adjective can have three, two, or one parts. For example:

celer, celeris, celere = swift, quick

3rd Declension adjectives may list all three genders in this order: masculine, feminine, neuter.

fortis, forte = strong, brave

3rd Declension adjectives may list the three genders in this order: masculine & feminine (first form), neuter.

potens, (potentis) = powerful

3rd Declension adjectives may list the three genders in this order: masculine & feminine & neuter (first form), Genitive singular (2nd form).

Prepositions

A preposition is a word—and almost always a very small, very common word—that shows direction.

Common English prepositions: across, between, down, from, in, off, on, over, off, through, with

Common Latin prepositions: a/ab, ad, cum, de, e/ex, inter, sine, super, per, pro, trans

In a sentence, prepositions will usually be followed by a noun or pronoun in the Ablative case or Accusative case. A prepositional phrase in the Ablative or Accusative case occurs when a preposition "pairs up" with an Ablative/Accusative case noun to its right in a sentence.

Example of Prepositional Phrase in the Ablative Case:

Preposition: in

Prepositional Phrase: in aqua

Preposition + Ablative Case Noun: in + aqua (Ablative singular)

Prepositional Phrase Translation: in the water

Verbs

A Latin verb normally has four parts to it in this order: 1st principal part, 2nd principal part, 3rd principal part, 4th principal part. For example:

ambulo, ambulare, ambulavi, ambulatus, -a, -um

Ambulo is the 1st principal part of this verb.

Ambulare is the 2nd principal part of this verb.

Ambulavi is the 3rd principal part of this verb.

Ambulatus, -a, -um is the 4th principal part of this verb.

Identifying a Vocabulary Entry in a Latin Sentence

For the most part, Latin vocabulary words do not appear in a Latin sentence exactly as written in the glossary. This is because nouns, adjectives, and pronouns appear in their declined forms in a Latin sentence. Likewise, verbs appear in their conjugated forms in a Latin sentence. The Toolbox has more information on how to recognize your Latin words as declined or conjugated in a sentence.
